title: 109_hr661
content: The "Riayan Tejeda Memorial Act of 2005" requires naturalization through service in combat zones during Operation Iraqi Freedom. Aliens who served honorably in combat zones during Operation Iraqi Freedom can be naturalized without following the usual requirements, by filing an application and taking the oath as specified by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Aliens who served honorably in combat zones during Operation Iraqi Freedom can be naturalized without usual requirements. No fees can be charged for naturalization applications, and State courts cannot charge fees unless required by state law. Overseas naturalization proceedings for members of the Armed Forces are also allowed. The Secretaries of Homeland Security, State, and Defense must ensure that naturalization processes are available at US embassies, consulates, and military installations overseas. Extension of posthumous benefits to surviving spouses, children, and parents. Extension of posthumous benefits to surviving spouses, children, and parents. Treatment as Immediate Relatives: Spouses of deceased U.S. citizens who served in the military in a combat zone and died as a result of their service are eligible for immigration benefits. Spouses and children of deceased U.S. citizens who served in the military and died in a combat zone can remain immediate relatives if the alien files a petition within 2 years of the citizen's death. Children of citizens who served in the military are also eligible for benefits. Marine Corps, Coast Guard, or Coast Guard Reserve members who die in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom due to service-related injury or disease can remain immediate relatives if the alien files a petition within 2 years of the citizen's death. Parents of US citizens who served in the military and died in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom can file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security for classification under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Aliens who are parents of US citizens who served in the military and died in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom can file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security for classification under the Immigration and Nationality Act within 2 years of the citizen's death. Aliens who are parents of US citizens who served in the military and died in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom can file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security for classification under the Immigration and Nationality Act within 2 years of the citizen's death. The petition shall be considered filed under section 204(a)(1)(A) of the Act, and a citizen described in the exception does not have to be 21 years of age for a parent to benefit. Additionally, applications for adjustment of status by surviving spouses, children, and parents are allowed under certain conditions. Aliens who were spouses, children, or parents of military personnel who served in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom and died as a result of their service may have their adjustment of status applications adjudicated even after their death. This provision applies to those who were granted posthumous citizenship. Aliens who were spouses, children, or parents of military personnel who served in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom and died as a result of their service may have their adjustment of status applications adjudicated even after their death. This provision applies to those who were granted posthumous citizenship under section 329A of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Spouses and children of lawful permanent resident aliens can be considered valid petitioners for immediate relative status under certain conditions. Aliens who were spouses, children, or parents of military personnel who served in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom and died as a result of their service may have their adjustment of status applications adjudicated even after their death. This provision applies to those who were granted posthumous citizenship under section 329A of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Spouses and children of lawful permanent resident aliens can be considered valid petitioners for immediate relative status under certain conditions. Spouse or child of an alien under section 201(b)(2)(A)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1151(b)(2)(A)(i)) are eligible for deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization. They may file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security for classification under the same Act. An alien who served honorably in the military in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom may file a petition for family-sponsored immigrant classification with the Secretary of Homeland Security. The spouse or child must file within 2 years to be eligible for deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization. An alien who served in Operation Iraqi Freedom and died as a result of service-related injury or disease may have their parents, who are lawful permanent resident aliens, file a petition for family-sponsored immigrant classification within 2 years. The parent may be eligible for deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization. An alien described in this paragraph served honorably in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom, died as a result of service-related injury or disease, and was granted posthumous citizenship. This allows for adjustment of status for the alien physically present in the United States. An alien present in the US can apply for adjustment of status to permanent residence if they are the beneficiary of a petition under specific subsections. Certain grounds of inadmissibility do not apply to aliens accorded immigration benefits under this section. Prohibition on benefits to survivors does not apply to relatives of individuals granted posthumous citizenship due to military service. Any surviving spouse, child, or parent of a US citizen who dies during honorable service in specified military branches in a combat zone related to Operation Iraqi Freedom may be naturalized. They must meet all requirements of the Immigration and Nationality Act, with an exception for prior residence. No prior residence or physical presence in the United States is required for naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act for surviving spouses, children, or parents of a US citizen who dies during honorable service in specified military branches in a combat zone related to Operation Iraqi Freedom. Priority for naturalization applications is given to applications filed under section 2 of the Act or under title III of the Immigration and Nationality Act for the naturalization of family members of individuals who have served in specified military branches in combat zones related to Operation Iraqi Freedom.
